note_models.name: Basilare

fields: [latex]Write the one-dimensional time-dependent Schrodinger equation for the wave function of a quantum particle of mass m[/latex]

[$$]-{\hbar^2 \over 2m}{\partial^2 \psi (x,t) \over \partial x^2}+V(x) \psi(x,t)=i \hbar \frac{\partial \psi(x,t)}{\partial t}[/$$]
[latex]If $\psi(x,t)$ is a solution, then also all the functions of the form $\psi_\phi(x,t)=e^{i \phi}\psi(x,t) $ are a solutions of the same equation.[/latex]
[latex]Born interpretation of the wave function $\psi(x)$[/latex]

[$$]\rho(x)=|\psi(x)|^2[/$$]
[latex]$\rho(x)$ it's the probability density of finding the particle in $x$. It's normalized, thus $\psi$ must be square-integrable.[/latex]
[latex]Properties of the solution psi of the time-dependent Shrodinger equation[/latex]

[latex]\begin{enumerate}
\item $\psi(x)$ must be normalized and square-integrable (Born interpretation): $\int_{-\infty}^\infty|\psi(x)|^2dx=1$
\item $\psi(x)$ must be finite for all x, otherwise the probability density would become infinite
\item $\psi(x)$ must be single-valued because we derive observable results
\item $\psi(x)$ and its derivative will be chosen to be continuos at least away from singularities of the potential. In this way we are compatible with the physical interpretation.
\end{enumerate}[/latex]
[latex]Continuity equation in the one-dimensional case[/latex]
[$$]\frac{\partial \rho(x,t)}{\partial t}=-\frac{\partial J(x,t)}{\partial x}[/$$]
[latex]Definitions of probability density and probability current[/latex]

[$$]\rho(x,t)=|\Psi(x,t)|^2=\Psi(x,t)\Psi^*(x,t)[/$$]
[$$]J(x,t)=\frac{i \hbar }{ 2m}\left[ -\Psi^*(x,t)\frac{\partial \Psi(x,t) }{ \partial x} + \Psi(x,t)\frac{\partial\Psi^*(x,t) }{ \partial x}\right][/$$]
[latex]Wronskian theorem[/latex]

[latex]If $z_1(x)$ and $z_2(x)$ are solutions of the following equations:
$$z_1''(x)+F_1(x)z_1(x)=0$$
$$z_2''(x)+F_2(x)z_2(x)=0$$
where $F_1(x)$ and $F_2(x)$ are generic functions, then the variation of the associated $W(z_1,z_2)$ in some interval (a,b) is given by:
$$W(z_1,z_2) \vert_a^b=\int_a^b\left[F_1(x)-F_2(x)\right]z_1(x)z_2(x)dx$$[/latex]
[latex]Definition of the Dirac delta[/latex]

[$$]\int_{-\infty}^\infty\delta(x-x_0)f(x)dx=f(x_0)[/$$]
[$$]\delta(x) \sim lim_{l\rightarrow \infty}{l \over \sqrt{\pi}}e^{-l^2x^2}[/$$]
[latex]Laplacian in spherical coordinates[/latex]

[$$]\nabla^2 ={\partial^2 \over \partial x^2} +{\partial^2 \over \partial y^2}+{\partial^2 \over \partial z^2}= {1 \over r^2} {\partial \over \partial r} \left( r^2 {\partial \over \partial r} \right) + {1 \over r^2 \mathrm{sin} \theta} {\partial \over \partial \theta} \left( \mathrm{sin} \theta {\partial \over \partial \theta} \right) +  {1 \over r^2} {1 \over \mathrm{sin}^2 \theta} {\partial^2 \over \partial \phi^2}[/$$]
[latex]Shrodinger equation for a particle moving in a effective potential[/latex]
[$$]-{\hbar^2 \over 2m}{d^2 \chi(r) \over dr^2}+\left [ U(r) + {\lambda \hbar^2 \over 2mr^2}\right ]\chi(r)=E\chi(r)[/$$]
[latex] Radial equation part of Shrodinger equation in polar form considering $$U(r)=-{Ze^2 \over r}$$[/latex]

[$$]{1 \over \rho^2}{d \over d\rho} \left( \rho^2 {dR(r(\rho)) \over d\rho} \right)+ \left [ {\delta \over \rho}+{1 \over 4}-{\lambda \over \rho^2} \right ] R=0[/$$]
[latex]Using: $\rho=\alpha r$, $\alpha=\sqrt{8m|E| \over \hbar^2}$, $\delta={Ze^2 \over \hbar} \left( {m \over 2|E|}\right)^{1 \over 2}$[/latex]
[latex]Energy levels of quantum harmonic oscillator[/latex]
[latex]$ E_n=\hbar \omega \left (n+{1\over 2}\right)$ with $n \ge 0$[/latex]
[latex]Hermite polynomials[/latex]
[$$]H_n(z)=(-1)^ne^{z^2}{d^n \over dz^n}\left( e^{-z^2}\right)[/$$]
[latex]Definition of Hilbert space[/latex]
[latex]An Hilbert space is a linear space endowed with a scalar product and such that it is complete and separable.[/latex]
[latex]Definition of "finite dimension" of a linear space[/latex]
[latex]A linear space is said to have finite dimension n if it is always possible to find n linearly independent elements but impossible to find n+1 linearly independent elements.[/latex]
[latex]Proprieties of the norm[/latex]

[latex]\begin{enumerate}
\item $||\phi||\ge 0$
\item $||a\phi||=|a| ||\phi||$
\item $||\phi + \psi||\le ||\phi||+||\psi||$ (triangle inequality)
\item $|(\phi,\psi)|\le||\phi||||\psi||$ (Schwarz inequality)
\end{enumerate}[/latex]
[latex]Definition of convergence of a sequence of elements[/latex]

[latex]A sequence $\psi_1,\psi_2,\dots,\psi_n,\dots$ of elements is said to converge to an element $\psi$ if the numerical sequence $||\psi_1-\psi||,\dots,||\psi_n-\psi||,\dots$ converges to zero.[/latex]
[latex]Definition of closet set[/latex]
[latex]A set is called closed if it contains all its limit points[/latex]
[latex]Definition of dense set[/latex]
[latex]A set U is said to be dense in S if U together with all its limit points is equal to S[/latex]
[latex]Enunciate of Cauchy convergence criterion[/latex]

[latex]A sequence $\psi_1,\psi_2,\dots,\psi_n,\dots$ satisfies the Cauchy criterion if for each $\varepsilon >0$ there exist an integer N such that $||\psi_m-\psi_n||\le \varepsilon$ for all $n,m\ge N$
In a matematical way:
$$ \forall \varepsilon > 0 \quad \exists k \in N : ||\psi_m-\psi_n|| \le \varepsilon \quad \forall n,m\ge k $$
[/latex]
[latex]Definition of completeness[/latex]
[latex]A set S is said to be complete if all Cauchy sequences in S do converge to an element of S[/latex]
[latex]Definition of separability[/latex]
[latex]A set S is said to be separable if for any $\psi \in S$ and $\varepsilon >0$ there exist a $\psi_n$, of a countable sequence, such that $||\psi-\psi_n|| < \varepsilon$ [/latex]
[latex]Definition of orthonormal sequence[/latex]
[latex]A sequence ${\psi_n}\in S$ is said to be orthonormal if $(\psi_m,\psi_n)=\delta_{m,n}$ for any two elements $\psi_n$ and $\psi_m$ in the sequence[/latex]
[latex]Definition of complete orthonormal system[/latex]

[latex]An orthonormal set $ \{ \psi_n \} \in S$ is said to be a complete othonormal system if there exist no $\psi \ne \omega$ orthogonal to every element of the sequence:
$$(\psi,\psi_k)=0\quad \forall k \quad \rightarrow \quad \psi=\omega$$[/latex]
[latex]Write the definition of linear variety and closed linear variety[/latex]

[latex]Let U be a set of elements of an Hilbert space. The set of all the linear combinations of the vectors in U is again a linear space, called the linear variety spanned by U. If we add all its limit points, we obtain a closed linear variety that contains U, which we shall denote with [U]: this is the closed linear variety spanned by U.[/latex]
[latex]3 satisfied conditions of a complete orthonormal set[/latex]

[latex]
$S=\{\psi_n\}$ it's an othonormal set. It is complete if and only if one of the following three conditions is satisfied:
\begin{enumerate}
\item for any $\psi \in S \quad \psi=\sum_ka_k\psi_k,\quad$ where $a_k=(\psi_k,\psi)$ 
\item the closed linear variety spanned by $\{\psi_k\}$ is equal to S
\item for any pair of elements $\psi,\phi\in S,\quad (\psi,\phi)=\sum_k(\psi,\psi_k)(\psi_k,\phi)$
\end{enumerate}[/latex]
[latex]Definition of Hermitian operator[/latex]
[latex]An operator is said to be Hermitian if $\hat{T}=\hat{T}^\dagger$[/latex]
[latex]Definition of unitary operator[/latex]
[latex]An operator $\hat{U}$ is said to be unitary if $\hat{U}\hat{U}^\dagger=\hat{U}^\dagger\hat{U}=I$[/latex]
[latex]Write when the set of all discrete and continuous eigenvectors is complete[/latex]

[latex]The set of all discrete and continuous eigenvectors, $\psi_k,\psi_\lambda$ is said to be compete if for any $\phi \in H$
$$\phi=\sum_k(\psi_k,\phi)\psi_k+\int(\psi_\lambda,\phi)\psi_\lambda d\lambda$$
and for any pair $\phi,\chi \in H$
$$(\phi,\chi)=\sum_k(\phi_k,\psi_k)(\psi_k,\chi)+\int(\phi,\psi_\lambda)(\psi_\lambda,\chi) d\lambda$$[/latex]
[latex]Definition of hypermaximal operator[/latex]

[latex]An hypermaximal operator is an hermitian operator with complete spectrum .
We shall assume that all the hermitian operators are hypermaximal.[/latex]
[latex]Postulate 1 of CLASSICAL mechanics[/latex]

[latex]The initial state of a system is given by a point $(q_0 , p_0)$ in phase space.
The states of the system at any later time are also points in phase space.
[/latex]
[latex]Postulate 2 of CLASSICAL mechanics[/latex]

[latex]The time evolution is given by Hamilton’s equations of motion:
$$\dot{q}=\{q,H\}_{P.B.}, \quad \dot{p}=\{p,H\}_{P.B.}$$
[/latex]
[latex]Postulate 3 of CLASSICAL mechanics[/latex]

[latex]The observables are real functions F(q,p) defined on the phase space. 
The measured quantities are the values of F on the points of the trajectory.[/latex]
[latex]Postulate 1 of QUANTUM mechanics[/latex]
[latex]The initial state of a quantum system is an element $\ket{A}$ of an Hilbert space. The states obtained by time evolution are also elements of the Hilbert space.[/latex]
[latex]Postulate 2 of QUANTUM mechanics[/latex]

[latex]The time evolution of a state of a quantum system is given by the time-dependent Schrodinger equation:
$$i\hbar{\partial \ket{\psi} \over \partial t}=\hat{H} \ket{\psi}$$
[/latex]
[latex]Postulate 3 of QUANTUM mechanics[/latex]

[latex]The observables of a quantum system are hyper-maximal Hermitian operators defined on the Hilbert space of the states of the system. The outcomes of a measurement of an observable are the eigenvalues of the corresponding Hermitian operator.[/latex]
[latex]Postulate 4 of QUANTUM mechanics[/latex]
[latex]A system is prepared by measuring a complete set of commuting operators.[/latex]
[latex]Postulate 5 of QUANTUM mechanics.[/latex]

[latex]The sistem has been prepared in the state $\ket{\psi_0}$ at the time $t=0$ and let this state evolve until the time t is reached. At the time t the state of the system is $\ket{\psi} $. Since $\hat O$ it's an observable the set of all its eigenstates $\{\ket{o_i}\}$ is a complete set of orthonormal states on which one can expand $\ket{\psi}$:
$$\ket{\psi}=\sum_i c_i \ket{o_i}$$
Then the probability of finding $o_i$ in a measurement of $\hat O$ is
$$P_{o_i}=|c_i|^2$$
[/latex]
[latex]Postulate 6 of QUANTUM mechanics.[/latex]
[latex] Measurement postulate: if we perform a measure of an observable $\hat O$, we make the state $\ket{\psi}$ to collapse on one of the eigenstates of $\hat O$[/latex]
[latex]Postulate 7 of QUANTUM mechanics.[/latex]

[latex] Correspondence principle: We can obtain some quantum observables from the corresponding classical by replacing $q,p$ with the associated quantum operators $\hat q, \hat p$. Also, Poisson brackets can be coverted in commutation brackets divided by $i \hbar$. Anyway, there exist quantum observables without classical analogous and coming from the classical one we must care about ordering of the $\hat q$ and $\hat p$[/latex]
[latex]Write the classical angular momentum in vectorial form and components form, then show the operatorial form.[/latex]

[latex]$$\vec {L}=\vec {x} \times \vec {p} $$
$$L_x=yp_z-zp_y \qquad L_y=zp_x-xp_z \qquad L_z=xp_y-yp_x$$
$$\hat L_x=\hat y \hat p_z- \hat z \hat p_y = -i \hbar \left (y \frac{\partial}{\partial z} - z \frac{\partial}{\partial y} \right ) $$
$$\hat L_y=\hat z \hat p_x- \hat x \hat p_z = -i \hbar \left (z \frac{\partial}{\partial x} - x \frac{\partial}{\partial z} \right ) $$
$$\hat L_z=\hat x \hat p_y- \hat y \hat p_x = -i \hbar \left (x \frac{\partial}{\partial y} - y \frac{\partial}{\partial x} \right ) $$
[/latex]

[latex]Write the results of the following commutators:

$\left [ \hat x_i , \hat p_j \right ]$

$\left [ \hat L_x , \hat L_y \right ] $

$\left [ \hat J_i , \hat J_j \right ]$

$\left [ \hat J_i , \hat J^2 \right ]$

$\left [ \hat J_z , \hat J_{(+)} \right ]$

$\left [ \hat J_z , \hat J_{(-)} \right ]$

$\left [ \hat J_{(+)} , \hat J_{(-)} \right ]$
[/latex]

[latex]
$\left [ \hat x_i , \hat p_j \right ] = i \hbar \delta_ {i,j}$

$\left [ \hat L_x , \hat L_y \right ] = i \hbar \hat L_z $

$\left [ \hat J_i , \hat J_j \right ] = i \hbar \varepsilon _{ijk} \hat J _k $

$\left [ \hat J_i , \hat J^2 \right ] =0 $

$\left [ \hat J_z , \hat J_{(+)} \right ] = \hbar \hat J _{(+)} $

$\left [ \hat J_z , \hat J_{(-)} \right ] = - \hbar \hat J _{(-)}$

$\left [ \hat J_{(+)} , \hat J_{(-)} \right ] =  2 \hbar \hat J _{z}$
[/latex]
[latex]Write the common eigenstates of $\hat J^2$ and $ \hat J_z$[/latex]

[latex]

\[ 
  \begin{cases}
    \hat J^2 \left| \lambda , m \right\rangle  = \hbar ^2 \lambda \left| \lambda , m \right\rangle      \\
    \hat J _z \left| \lambda , m \right\rangle =\hbar m \left| \lambda , m \right\rangle  \\
  \end{cases}
\]
[/latex]
[latex]Write the definition of spherical harmonics and write the components of the orbital angular momentum in polar coordinates[/latex]

[latex]

$$\braket{r,\vartheta,\varphi | l,m}=Y_{l,m}(\vartheta, \varphi )$$

$$\hat L_x=i\hbar \left( sin\varphi {\partial \over \partial \vartheta}+cot \vartheta cos\varphi {\partial \over \partial \varphi} \right)$$
$$\hat L_y=i\hbar \left( -cos\varphi {\partial \over \partial \vartheta}+cot \vartheta sin\varphi {\partial \over \partial \varphi} \right)$$
$$\hat L_x=-i\hbar {\partial \over \partial \varphi}$$
[/latex]
[latex]Write the eigenvalue problem $\hat L_z \ket{l,m}=m\hbar \ket{l,m}$ in the rappresentation of $\ket{r,\vartheta, \varphi}$ and his solution[/latex]

[latex]$$-i\hbar {\partial \over \partial \varphi} Y_{l,m}(\vartheta, \varphi)=m\hbar Y_{l,m}(\vartheta, \varphi)$$

$$Y_{l,m}(\vartheta, \varphi)={e^{im\varphi} \over \sqrt{2 \pi}}\Theta^m_l(\vartheta)$$
[/latex]
[latex]Express the operators $\hat L_{(+)}$ and $\hat L_{(-)}$ in polar coordinates[/latex]
[latex]$$\hat L _{(\pm)}= \hat L_x \pm i \hat L_y=\hbar e^{\pm i \varphi}\left( \pm {\partial \over \partial \vartheta } +i cot \vartheta {\partial \over \partial \varphi } \right)$$[/latex]
[latex]From the momentum in polar coordinates, retrieve the general expression of $\Theta _l^m(\vartheta)$ and $Y_{l,m}(\vartheta, \varphi)$[/latex]

[latex]
$$\Theta _l^m(\vartheta) = {1 \over \hbar^{l-m} } {1 \over \sqrt{2l!} } \sqrt{ (l+m)! \over (l-m)! } \hat L_{(-)}^{l-m} \Theta_l^l(\vartheta)$$ 
$$Y_{l,m}(\vartheta, \varphi)=(-1)^l \sqrt{2l+1 \over 4 \pi } \sqrt{ (l+m)! \over (l-m)! } e^{im \varphi} sin^{-m}\vartheta { d^{l-m} \over d(cos \vartheta)^{l-m} }(sin\vartheta)^{2l} $$
[/latex]
[latex]Write $ \psi $ in the spherical harmonics rappresentation[/latex]
[$$]\psi(\vartheta,\varphi) = \sum _l \sum _m c_{l,m} Y_{l,m}(\vartheta, \varphi)[/$$]
[latex]Write the conditions to start talking about addition of angular momenta.[/latex]

[latex]Consider two systems with given angular momenta. We have:
$$\hat J^{(T)}_i = \hat J^{(1)}_i + \hat J^{(2)}_i $$
$\hat J^{(T)}$ has its own spectrum of eigenvalues.
[/latex]
[latex]The two sets of commuting operator that came from $\left [ \hat J_i ^{(1)} , \hat J_j ^{(2)} \right ] = 0 $[/latex]

[latex]
$$(\hat J^{(1)} ) ^2 \qquad (\hat J^{(2)} ) ^2 \qquad \hat J^{(1)}_z \qquad \hat J^{(2)}_z$$

$$(\hat J^{(1)} ) ^2 \qquad (\hat J^{(2)} ) ^2 \qquad (\hat J^{(T)} ) ^2 \qquad \hat J^{(T)}_z$$

[/latex]
[latex]Write the eingenvaules of the 2 sets of commuting operators in the addition of angular momenta[/latex]

[latex]
Il primo:

$$(\hat J ^{(1)})^2 \ket{} = \hbar^2 j^{(1)}(j^{(1)} + 1) \ket{} $$

$$(\hat J ^{(2)})^2 \ket{} = \hbar^2 j^{(2)}(j^{(2)} + 1) \ket{} $$

$$(\hat J ^{(1)})_z \ket{} = \hbar m^{(1)} \ket{} $$

$$(\hat J ^{(2)})_z \ket{} = \hbar m^{(2)} \ket{} $$

Il secondo:

$$(\hat J ^{(1)})^2 \ket{} = \hbar^2 j^{(1)}(j^{(1)} + 1) \ket{} $$

$$(\hat J ^{(2)})^2 \ket{} = \hbar^2 j^{(2)}(j^{(2)} + 1) \ket{} $$

$$(\hat J ^{(T)})^2 \ket{} = \hbar^2 j^{(T)}(j^{(T)} + 1) \ket{} $$

$$(\hat J ^{(T)})_z \ket{} = \hbar m^{(T)} \ket{} $$

[/latex]
[latex]What is the dimension of the space of the states $\ket{j_1,j_2,m_1,m_2}$ ?[/latex]
[latex]Write the two observations to write $\ket{j^T,m^T} $ in the basis of $\ket{m_1,m_2}$ and the relation that comes from those[/latex]

[latex]\begin{enumerate}
\item Every vector $\ket{m_1,m_2}$ is an eigenstate of $\hat J^T_z$ with the corresponding  eigenvalue $m^T=m_1+m_2$ that is $\hat J ^T_z \ket{m_1,m_2}=\hbar (m_1+m_2)\ket{m_1,m_2}$
\item Say $N(j^T)$ the number of vectors in the space of $\ket{m_1,m_2}$ given a $j^T$ and $n(m^T)$ the number of states $\ket{m_1,m_2}$ which have the same $m^T$
\end{enumerate}

Then we have the relation: $n(m^T)=\sum _{j^T \ge |m^T|} N(j^T)$[/latex]
[latex]Write the three possible cases of values that $n(m^T)$ can reach. Try to imagine the example with $j_1= {7 \over 2}$ and $j_2=2$[/latex]

[latex]
\[
   n(m^T) = \begin{cases}
        0 & \text{ if }  |m^T| > j_1+j_2\\
        j_1+j_2+1-m^T &  \text{ if }  j_1+j_2 \ge |m^T| \ge |j_1-j_2|\\
        2j_2+1 &  \text{ if }  |j_1-j_2|\ge m^T \ge 0
\end{cases}
\]
[/latex]
